body:
### Describe your issue

I don't really have a solution to this right now... just some partial thoughts.

We (now) accept a lot of true unicode inputs (i.e. unicode filenames, unicode source code, unicode comments) where as previously we didn't and they're kind of under-tested.

We largely store everything as an `EncodedString` which just behaves like a normal Python string with respect to string formatting.

However, for the most part unicode inputs shouldn't make it into our output source file. They should either be `punycodify`ied (which also ends up with an `EncodedString` but one that consists just of ascii) or converted with `EncodedString.as_c_string_literal()` (which I think ends up with a regular Python string).

For the most part it's a mistake if `"%s" % some_arbitrary_encoded_string` gets into our code (or the modern formatted/fstring equivalent) but we get away most of the time because most of our tests use ASCII. It would be good if `EncodedString` was able to enforce that itself somehow to catch all the places we've missed.
title: Avoid `EncodedString` getting into the output
